title: News and Society
requirements:
UGEC2623 is double-coded with COMM2210. 
Not for GCOM; COMM Majors; and students who have taken COMM2210, 2910 or UGEC2621. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2623 is double-coded with COMM2210.)  This course talks about the characteristics and functioning of news, and its important role and functions in society. News is vital to us as it brings latest information of the day, helps create public opinion, educate our young generations, monitor the government and the powerful, as well as provide relaxation to our busy lives. To understand the news can essentially help us know our society. Various concepts and theories from the mass communication discipline are introduced together with some perspectives from other social sciences. Real-life examples from Hong Kong and abroad are analyzed.Students are first introduced to the unique nature of news and different types of news as found in both print and electronic media. Some new news formats, including free dailies, online newspapers, network social media and citizen journalism, are discussed in both international and local contexts. Relationships between journalism and closely related professions such as advertising and public relations are explicated in order to understand the actual functioning of news, as well as its impact on society. The professional concerns of the field of journalism and individual’s news consumption habits are also highlighted in the course.After taking this course, students will be able to understand more about news and its relationship with the society. They should be able to critically evaluate news and social phenomena. It is hoped that they can become wise news consumers and well-informed citizens.
outcome: Students will be able to describe the nature and characteristics of news.Students will know about current affairs and can differentiate different types of news and their impacts.Students will be equipped with news analytical skills and can apply them to study major news phenomena competently.Students will be able to explore the role of news in society and discuss the relationship between news and society.Students will be trained as wise news consumers and critical citizens.
syllabus: The course consists of several parts. The first part sets the stage by examining the relationship between news and society, the nature and characteristics of news, as well as inviting students to reflect on their news reading habits. The second part deals with various major types of news, including social news, political news, entertainment news, and international news. The third part is about some emerging news trends in society, including the rapid rise of free newspapers, online newspapers and the new social network media as news channels. The final part discusses institutional relationships among news, advertising, public relations, and other social sectors. The reflection on journalistic professionalism and media ethics serve to round up and highlight the role and responsibilities of news in society. The following is an outline of this course: Week 1   Introduction: News and SocietyThe course starts by introducing the role of journalism as a vital social institution and its unique function as the often-quoted "fourth estate" of the government. But in fact news serves to monitor the government and the society, and thus freedom of the press is important not only to the journalists but to the general public. Contribution of newswork to the proper maintenance of the public sphere and establishment of a civil society is emphasized. Key concepts: journalism as social institution, journalism as the fourth estate, press freedom, public sphere Week 2   What is News: Characteristics and PerspectivesNews is a complex social phenomenon. It is so familiar to us but yet a simple and clear definition cannot be satisfactorily reached among academics and practitioners. Many agree that "immediacy", "importance" and "interest" are the three most important components. Others see news as some sort of deviant events. Some scholars regard news as vital social information while others think of it as a commercial product. Objectivity can be regarded as a noble ideal but some say it is a "strategic ritual". Scholars from the humanistic tradition would treat it primarily as a "speech act". Key concepts: definitions of news, the three “Is” of news, news as deviance, objectivity as strategic ritual, news net, humanistic perspectives of news Week 3   Cultivating Good News Reading HabitsNews consumption patterns were stable in the past but are now showing great changes due to the coming of the Internet age. People tend to read less print newspapers and spend more time getting information online. This is especially true for the younger generations who practically grow up together with the Internet. How can we instill the value of news reading to the young people? How can they become smarter readers, no matter which news venues/channels they tune to? New technologies are a threat to existing media but they also open up new opportunities and possibilities. It is essential for our students to be news literate in order to become an informed and critical citizen. Key concepts: changing news use patterns, news consumer, critical citizenship, media education, technological impact Week 4   Social News: Taste Strata of Mass and EliteNews about the society can vary according to the orientations of news organizations and the tastes of the reading/viewing public. The elite class has different taste preference over news when compared with the mass public. Fierce competition and marketization have driven many news organizations to go down the road of tabloidization and McDonaldization. They tend to hype the news and respond more to market "wants" instead of social "needs". Key concepts: tabloidization, McDonaldization, market driven-journalism, hyping Week 5   Political News: Monitoring Those in PowerNews is always intertwined with the government, politicians and those who have power in society. Various political forces want to control or influence the press in order to gain advantages. They feed and spin stories to the media, which on the other hand try to play the watchdog function and report news responsibly. News coverage in election settings will be examined to see how journalists and politicians interact with each other, and whether the public is properly informed. Key concepts: spin doctoring, watchdog function, social responsibility theory, media and election, stereotyping Week 6   Entertainment News: "Interesting", Not "Public Interest" Some people love entertainment news. They are keen on the "interesting" acts of or self-directed promotion by certain celebrities and have little concern over "public interest". As a result, entertainment news tends to be trivial or muckraking. The paparazzi teams sent by news organizations could not care less about invasion of privacy or damaging celebrities' reputations. The blurring of boundaries (between truth and falsehood, right and wrong, public and private, etc.) is something we should be aware of when reading this type of news. Key concepts: trivialization, paparazzi, personal muckraking, blurring of boundaries, invasion of privacy Week 7   International News: Our Window on the WorldThe course will talk about international news as the world is getting more and more global and integrated. It is essentially our window to look at the world outside. Between nations, diplomacy is often done through news reporting, which significantly reflects national interests. The major international news agencies play an important role. Journalists usually try hard to "domesticate" foreign news to make it more attractive to local audience. Key concepts: media and national interest, public policy, media diplomacy, domestication of news Week 8   Free Newspapers: The New Model That WorksTraditionally, TV is free but newspaper is paid. But in the past few decades, paid TV channels have quickly emerged as well as free newspapers. Print newspapers rely on both advertising and subscription or single copy sales. This business model is upset by the free newspapers which rely solely on advertising. People find that being free is irresistible, and they are less concerned about the quantity and quality of news as long as it is free of charge. What are the implications for the future of journalism? Would it popularize newspaper reading or downgrade the quality of journalism, or both? How do free dailies, paid dailies and online dailies interact? These are evolving issues worthy of closer examination. Key concepts: distribution-driven journalism, free vs. paid, Metro Daily formula, work-habitation patterns, interactions among different types of newspapers Week 9   Online Newspapers: News in the Internet AgeGoing online is a relatively new phenomenon for the press starting in the mid-1990s. It began as a low-cost spin-off that carried big promises both in terms of revenue and readership. The actual result favors the latter but not the former, and the journalism industry is still seeking a workable business model for online newspapers. But onlineDailies do revolutionize news delivery and its content because of its electronic and digital format. A new marketplace is forged but its potential has not been fully realized. Whether online newspapers would eventually replace the print versions remains an intriguing question for both the academics and the practitioners. Key concepts: electronic marketplace, information marketplace, opinion marketplace, virtual media space, media format Week 10 Social Network Media as News ChannelsIn the past decade, new social network media have become so popular that they also begin to act as news source and serve as a platform for news dissemination. What are their relationships with traditional news organizations? How do they affect the nature, delivery and quality of news? Scholars differentiate the role of traditional journalists as "gatekeeping" from the new role of online journalists as "gatewatching". Is citizen journalism in the Internet age a blessing or a curse? Would there be generational differences? All these questions will be explored in the course. Key concepts: alternative media, Facebook, Twitter, blogging, citizen journalism, gatekeeping, gatewatching Week 11 News and Advertising: Any Strings Attached with the Money?News and advertising seem to be inseparable worldwide. Journalists work together with advertising and marketing people to bring both news and product information to the readers/audiences. But the journalistic side and the market side of a news organization have different and even opposing ideals and goals. They are in constant battle but have to rely on the other for survival. How can news be immune from unwanted advertising influence? Why is public broadcasting possible but not public print journalism? Key concepts: journalistic theory vs. market theory, theory of low involvement, types of advertising, commercialization, sponsorship  Week 12 News and Public Relations: How to Influence the PressJournalists and public relations people constitute another pair of actors in constant tension and cooperation. Journalists need news sources and public relations practitioners provide news and information to news organizations. But public relations people are often accused of staging pseudo-events in order to gain publicity and propaganda. They try to influence the press and get coverage. In recent years, many journalists leave the profession and join the public relations field as they know how news work and how to gain press coverage. It is an interesting topic and has major implications for the content and quality of news reporting. Key concepts: pseudo-events, staging, manufacturing consent, propaganda model Week 13 Rethinking News: Professionalism, Ethics, and AlternativesThis week is a wrap-up of the course by focusing on media professionalism and ethics. How can journalists do their job properly under all sorts of constraints? Can they adhere to a high standard of media ethics? Can news reflects different perspectives and interests in the society? Is the noble ideal of public journalism a viable alternative? How can news better serve our society and the general public? It is hoped that students will be able to reflect on these questions through the readings and the various assignments in this course. Key concepts: journalistic professionalism, media ethics, multi-perspectival news, public journalism

title: Internet, Digital Media and Information Society
requirements:
UGEC2624 is double-coded with COMM2940.Not for Journalism and Communication; Global Communication Majors; and students who have taken COMM2940. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2624 is double-coded with COMM2940.) This course aims to examine a number of key issues that are closely related to developments in Internet and digital media. The advent of communication technologies has brought tremendous changes to media environments. Media convergence and participatory culture are two most notable emerging trends that have contributed to new forms of media production and consumption. Students will be introduced to key concepts and perspectives in appreciating, analyzing and evaluating such trends. Through case studies about social media, streaming entertainment, Internet celebrities, networked social movements and digital surveillance culture, etc, students will review the many tacit assumptions about Internet in their everyday life.
outcome: After taking this course, students will be able to: (1) describe and explain the roles of Internet in the formation of the contemporary society and how it leads to social change; (2) discuss various social and cultural phenomena in relation to the development of Internet; (3) evaluate different claims about the impact of communication technologies in information society;  (4) identify and analyze core debates about Internet, digital media and information society; and (5) become an informed and ethical user in the new media environment.
syllabus: Week 1 Phenomena, problems and issues In this introductory class, we will examine a few recent viral cases in social media and discuss two recurring themes, namely convergence and participation, in this course.   Week 2 When old media were new… In this class, we will dive into a few key episodes in the history of communication technologies. We will review and discuss how various factors have contributed to the invention and development of communication fads.   Week 3 Mediated memories: How we remember and are remembered? Communication technologies have been important memory devices in human history. We will trace how communication technologies co-evolved with memory practices.   Week 4 Social media: How we connect and are connected? What media are not “social media”? Media always facilitate networking in different forms. We will reconsider what differentiates the social media we know of today from previous generations of social media.   Week 5 Dating apps and romance  The meanings of ‘romance’ and ‘intimacy’ have undergone sweeping changes with the advent of dating apps in smartphones. In this class, we will examine the features of these apps and uncover their assumptions underlying ‘love’.   Week 6 MOOC and learning  Massive Open Online Courses are introducing new forms of teaching, learning and academic accreditation. In a broader sense, how has Internet transformed learning? We will critically evaluate some popular claims in this aspect.     Week 7 KOL and public opinions Key Opinion Leaders are also known as social influencers or sometimes internet celebrities. They are seen to exert increasing influence in ‘public opinions’ or ‘public sentiments’.　In this class, we will revisit earlier communication theory regarding two-step flow of information and see how Internet has brought new practices in shaping public opinions.    Week 8 Streaming media and entertainment  In this class, we will focus on the case of streaming media and discuss how entertainment is changed in the Internet era. We will also consider how this in turn affects the production, distribution and consumption of media products.   Week 9 - 10 Haters and comment culture Comment culture is a notable Internet phenomenon. Instead of looking at ‘likes’, we focus on the mechanisms behind ‘dislikes’ and the behaviors of ‘haters’.    Week 11 Protest mobilization and social movements Internet is seen to be a key factor in protest mobilization. We will examine some key elements in social movements and discuss how social media, for example, have contributed (or not) in the mobilization process.    Week 12 Surveillance and sensor society  The classic ‘big brother’ thesis is discussed with a careful consideration of many emerging practices in surveillance and self-surveillance. The idea of ‘sensor society’ will be introduced to see how we are (in)voluntarily contributing to a productive surveillance culture.    Week 13 Hello future!  In this final class, we will reconsider the two central themes of convergence and participation and make both informed and wild guesses for the future.

title: Economic Insecurity and Social Security in Global Contexts
requirements:
UGEC2631 is double-coded with SOWK2160. 
Not for Social Work Majors; and students who have taken SOWK2160. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2631 is double-coded with SOWK2160.) This course aims at analyzing economic insecurity from a global perspective and introducing social security as a societal measure to combat economic insecurity. Specifically, this course will examine the sources of economic insecurity of the individual and the relationship between globalization and economic insecurity. It will also discuss the philosophy, development, characteristics and functions of different types of social security measures in different countries and analyze current debates on the future development of social security in national and cross-national perspective.
outcome: Upon the completion of this course, students should be able to: 1.        comprehend the meaning and nature of economic insecurity in globalized world; 2.        understand the extent of economic insecurity and poverty in Hong Kong and in other societies; 3.        acquire knowledge on social security as a societal measure to combat economic insecurity and poverty; 4.        become familiar with the political and economic contexts in the development of social security, national differences in the provision of economic security, major types of provisions and issues of social security; 5.        analyze contemporary debates regarding the philosophy and future direction of social security development in national and cross-national perspective.

Economic and financial globalization and economic insecurity   Understanding global poverty 1. Concepts and definitions 2. Theories of poverty causation 3. Measuring poverty, poverty incidence and trends 4. Strategies to combat poverty and economic insecurity 5. Global overview of economic insecurity and poverty 6. Global goals, frameworks and strategies in eradicating poverty and economic insecurity   Social security: a strategy to combat poverty and economic insecurity 1. Concept, definitions, objectives and scope 2. Historical trends in social security development 3. Types and branches of social security provisions and their underpinning values and principles 4. Structural components of social security provisions 5. Welfare ideologies and social security systems 6. Global overview of social security practices 7. Development and provisions of social security in Hong Kong in comparison with other countries and jurisdictions – similarities and differences     Old age and economic insecurity 1. A global perspective on economic insecurity and poverty in old age 2. Measures to relieve economic insecurity and hardship in old age – options, strengths and weaknesses 3. Mandatory Provident Fund Vs. Old Age Pension Scheme 4. Balancing fiscal viability and financial security of old age   Unemployment, underemployment and economic insecurity 1. Unemployment & underemployment: global trends & regional characteristics 2. Economic insecurity associated with unemployment and underemployment 3. Measures to combat economic insecurity associated with unemployment and underemployment – social security, active labour market policies & community economic development – local and overseas 4.  The working poor   Economic insecurity arising from sickness; & Health Care 1. Economic insecurity associated with sickness and health risks 2. Access to affordable and sustainable health care – problems and options   Conclusion 1. Contributions, criticisms and issues of social security programs in combating economic insecurity and global poverty 2. Debates and controversies on future development of social security in national and cross-national perspective 3. Integration of social security and other public and social measures

description: (UGEC2632 is double-coded with COMM2920.) title: Media and Social Development in Mainland China
requirements:
UGEC2634 is double-coded with COMM2140. 
Not for GCOM; COMM Majors; and students who have taken COMM2140. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2634 is double-coded with COMM2140.)  The course is designed around two major themes, namely media and social development in Mainland China since the founding of the People's Republic in 1949. Using key concepts and theories from the political economy of media and developmental communication studies, it introduces students to different periods of media reform and social change from the era of Chairman Mao to the period of "harmonious society". Emphasis is attached to post-1989 media regulatory systems, media industrialization, and their influence on the meeting of such developmental goals as poverty alleviation, democratization, and communication empowerment.The course will examine Mainland China's key media sectors including the printing press (newspapers and magazines), film and broadcasting media (radio and TV), and new networked communication tools (Internet and mobile phone) as well as alternative social formations through Internet activism, non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and transnational developmental projects. The course will identify and discuss several ongoing debates, and the ensuing actions, held by different stakeholders, including governmental officials, media producers, educators, activists, international agencies, and the general audiences. Wider implications to public policy will be identified. There will also be discussions of current affairs related to media and social development in the country.Students will be able to describe the key characteristics of contemporary Mainland Chinese media and their roles in facilitating or obstructing development towards the ideals of a "new China".
outcome: 1.      Students will be able to describe key characteristics of media in Mainland China.  2.      Students will be able to discuss how media influences social development and how new social formations trigger media reform in Mainland China.3.      Students will be able to identify phases of media and social development in Mainland China and differentiate policymaking rationales in different media sectors (printing, broadcasting, networked media) and types of social movements. 4.      Students will be able to discuss competing arguments about the role of media reform in China's modernization drive. 5.      Students will be able to produce a media text that offers a critique to one of the historical periods, media industries, or controversial issues covered in the course.
syllabus: The course consists of five main parts: (I) theories of media, communication and social development (week 1 and 2); (II) history of media transformation in Mainland China since 1949 (week 3 and 4); (III) key media sectors (week 5 to 7); (IV) social movements and campaigns (week 8 to 10); and (V) institutional stakeholders (week 11 and 12). In each part, there will be a mixture of conceptual and practical information, of consensus and controversies, and of historical knowledge and current affairs. The class will also look at different disadvantaged social groups and their relationship with various media sectors and stakeholders both within and outside officialdom. The following is an outline of the course: Week 1  Introduction: Ideals of "New China"The first class will introduce students to (a) the pursuit of a "New China" that gave legitimacy to the rise of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) since the May Fourth Movement, and (b) classical theories of media and national development between 1950s and 1980s. It will also discuss the concept of 'social development' and give an overview of the course's core content.Key concepts: "New China", nation building, communication and development Week 2  Communist Media Theories: Political Control and Social DevelopmentThis class discusses Leninist press theory, its evolution in the Chinese party-state, and the rationale behind this historical transformation, including politico-economic considerations as well as trends in cultural and technological change. Key ideas of the mass line and ICTD (information and communication technologies and development) will also be discussed in the case of rural development.Key concepts: Leninist press theory, party-state, political control, the mass line, ICTD, rural development Week 3 and 4 Past and PresentThese two classes differentiate media and social development in Mainland China into three historical periods: 1949-1978; 1978-1989; and 1989-date.  What defines these periods? How are they different? Did previous periods pave the way for later trends of marketization and partial liberalization in the post-1989 era?Key concepts: The Maoist era, pre-1989 media reform, post-1989 reform, marketization, partial liberalization Weeks 5 to 7 Key Media SectorsZooming into China's printing media (newspaper and magazines), film and broadcasting media (radio and TV), and new networked media (Internet and mobile phone), these three classes provide a sector-specific analysis of China's media systems and their contributions to meeting goals of social development.  Issues of censorship and regulation will be introduced. Debates on the digital divide will also be discussed.Key concepts: printing media, film, broadcasting media, networked media, censorship, regulation, digital divide Weeks 8 to 10  Social Movements and CampaignsThese three classes focus on official efforts to modernize China using traditional and new media channels as well as alternative communication empowerment projects such as those led by domestic labor NGOs, environmental groups, and transnational civil society players. Studies in minority-nationality regions and with regard to disadvantaged groups such as women will be discussed along with the official project of "constructing new socialist countryside". Key concepts: "constructing new socialist countryside", activism, empowerment, feminist activism, environmental movement, minority nationalities, transnational civil society Week 11 and 12  Institutional StakeholdersWe will first return to China's media regulatory frameworks centered on the CCP's Central Propaganda Division (CPD) as well as several ministry-level governing bodies whose bureaucratic systems extend to lower levels of the party-state. Then in Week 12, we will look into China's journalism education system as another key institutional stakeholder. To what extent are the regulators and educators facilitating or hindering overall social development? Why? How could they do better? How could college students in Hong Kong play a meaningful role interacting with the stakeholders?Key concepts: CPD, local state, media governance, journalism education, democratization Week 13 Student Group Presentations and Course Wrap-UpStudents will present their final projects in the last class, which will end with the instructor's wrap-up of the course.

title: Social Media and Crisis Communication
requirements:
UGEC2636 is double-coded with COMM2813. 
Not for GCOM; COMM Majors; and students who have taken COMM2813. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2636 is double-coded with COMM2813.) With the advent of the new media technology, new forms of organizational crisis emerge. They are called Internet-mediated crises. A major difference between the Internet-mediated crises and the traditional crises lies in the intensive interactivity, collectivity, simultaneity and dialogic sphericity of the former. This very nature of Internet-mediated crisis makes it all the more hard to handle. A specialized and critical function of the public relations practice is the management of crisis. This course covers two major levels. The first level takes on a functionalism approach to crisis management. The second level takes on a more critical approach in public relations. Students will learn how crisis reflects complicity and dynamism between citizens and organizations in modern societies. They will acquire an enhanced appreciation of communication that can be brought to bear in such crisis situations and a greater familiarity with the interactivity of an organization and its stakeholders as well as the environments in times of crises. They will also gain more sensitivity in public demands of socially responsible practices in the business contexts.

title: Advertising and Society
requirements:
UGEC2638 is double-coded with COMM2840. 
Not for GCOM; COMM Majors; and students who have taken COMM2840. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2638 is double-coded with COMM2840.) In this course, students will analyze real life campaigns to understand major effects of advertising in everyday life. Students will examine topics like materialism and commercialization of friendship to see how advertising persuade consumers through subtle uses of messages. They will also decode the formation and shifting of values promoted by Government and green campaigns. The course will help students distinguish between authentic and mediated reality regarding topics on artificial perfection of body image, sexual objectification and gender stereotyping.
outcome: At the end of this course, students will:    1.     Identify the multifaceted effects of mass-mediated advertising messages along the dimensions of subliminal messaging, infusion of constructed meanings, and mediation of reality. 2.     Recognize the impacts of advertising on personal and psychological development. 3.     Critically analyze advertising messages and motivations. 4.     Investigate beyond the seemingly superficial phenomenon created by advertising into deeper issues related to living attitude and social values. 5.     Develop a curiosity towards real life campaigns that promote meaningful causes that benefit citizens in Hong Kong.
syllabus: I. SUBLIMINAL PERSUASION             Week 1: Subliminal Messaging and Materialism   This week will introduce briefly all three sections and emphasis more specifically on subliminal persuasion, using materialism, luxury branding in China as examples. China has replaced Japan as the second strongest economic power in the world in 2012. It has also surpassed the US to become the second largest luxury brand market in 2009, spending of $9.4 billion and accounting for 27.5% of total global sales of luxury brands in the world. The invasion of luxury brands will inevitably alter the spending culture in China. Luxury brand ads hint subtly that consumers using them belong to a higher social group in the society. Students will discuss the subliminal indicators of luxury brand ads and their effects on attitudes towards social status in the society.    Week 2: Commercialization of Friendship in Social Networking Sites   Social networking sites are dominating the media landscape among young people. Many viral ads are circulated through the disguise of sincere recommendations from friends, who actually share information for an incentive. This class will look into the core of this issue: should friendship be commercialized for personal gains?   Week 3: Properties, Personal Loan Ads and Wealth   The recent waves of glamorized Hong Kong properties ads disseminated in China led to grave consequences in raising the prices of flats in Hong Kong. The property ads In Hong Kong shape unrealistic desires in viewers to own a flat that demands a lifetime of hard earned salaries. Personal loan ads encourage a supposedly free life of spending with no responsibility. This lesson will discuss the dynamics of these subliminal messages in affecting one’s decision about how to spend his / her money.   Week 4: Political Campaigns and Elections   The presence of political campaigns in commercial media becomes prevalent these days due to the rise of democratization in the election process. This lesson will look into the various tactics and subliminal strategies used and manipulated in political advertising and its effects on public participation in election.   II. MEDIATION OF REALITY   Week 5: Beauty Ads and Body Image   This lesson will start with an in-depth look at the concept of mediation of reality, using studies conducted in Hong Kong that relate beauty and slimming product / service ads to a negative self-perceived body image in both men and women. Teenagers, in particular, are finding their self in their growing years by comparing themselves to the models in the ads. The gap between the idealized self and actual self creates frustrations among many. To bridge the gap, some fall for crash diets and some for desperate acts of plastic surgeries.   Week 6: Stereotypical Sex Ads and Gender Roles   This lesson looks into the relationship between commoditization and objectification of the body and the resultant stereotypical roles played by men and women. Students will be challenged to live beyond the fixed roles narrowly defined and presented in the pseudo-reality.   Week 7: Tutor King / Queen Ads and Education   The educational system in Hong Kong requires students to acquire incessant training and upgrading. Many tutors chanced this opportunity to create fast track learning to success by advertising their success rate of getting a student to obtain an As. This form of promotion alters students’ mentality to learning. Tutors acting as opinion leaders in ads create a trend of commercialized education.   Week 8: A “Copycat” Culture   “Copycat” China refers not only to the many cases of copying of products but also the imitation of ideas and other intellectual properties in China. Advertising is an industry that is keen on creativity, the very core element that sustains the industry. Piracy will suffocate the creative industry in the long run. Students will scan the creative landscape in China and learn to identify the seemingly original creative reality.   III. INFUSION OF CONSTRUCTED MEANINGS   Week 9: Freedom of Speech and the Press  This class will start examining the idea about meaning and value driven advertising/ advocacy. Recent cases show that advertising is affecting the press in Hong Kong and the Mainland has been censoring a lot of ads online and outdoor. What is the value of commercial speech? How much would the commercial speech be compromised? Will the censorship erode creativity, global branding strategy and business development? Students will investigate the longstanding struggle of the protection of speech in Hong Kong and the mainland.   Week 10: Globalizing and Standardization   Global brands launched by global advertising agencies bring about their unique culture from the country-of-origin into a foreign country. For a global brand to be successfully adopted by local citizens, the agencies need to accommodate the traditional culture. However, the global influence for standardization sometimes surpasses localization, resulting in a pervasive infusion of foreign values. The balance and consideration of both cultures are the center of discussion in this lesson. A few global campaigns around the world will be presented to demonstrate the delicate balance between globalization and localization.   Week 11: “Anti” Campaigns and Social Movements   This lesson will look into the value-driven impact and of Public Service Announcements (PSAs), including the anti-smoking, anti-drug and anti-AIDS campaigns on society. The lesson will also focus on the development, planning and execution of those campaigns. It is the purpose of the lesson to raise the awareness of the students in these cause advertising campaigns.   Week 12: Earth Hour, Outdoor Light Pollution and other Green Campaigns   Greenpeace and other environmental protection groups have been working on major campaigns to improve the living conditions of the world. A few successful green campaigns will be discussed in class to reveal their value shifting strategies.   Week 13: Food, Drug Ads and Public Health   World Health Organization has established the strong tie between advertising of high fat, salt and sugar (HFSS) food and obesity. While UK has exercised blanket ban of food advertising to children and many other countries following suit, the Broadcasting Authority in Hong Kong has only advised five cases in the past four years regarding HFSS food ads to children. This lesson will investigate the difficult path to policy change in the business sector in Hong Kong. Advertising of all medicinal products in Hong Kong is strictly controlled by the Undesirable Medical Advertisements Ordinance (Cap 231) (the UMAO). Section 3 of the UMAO provides for an outright prohibition against the publication of 'any advertisement likely to lead to the use of any medicine … for the purpose of treating … or preventing' any disease, disorder or abnormal physical state. However, some prominent direct-to-consumer prescription drug ads are produced and broadcasted in Hong Kong recently. DTC drug advertising will change the traditional beliefs towards doctor-patient relationship and the demand of name-brand drugs at the expense of generic or equally effective drugs. Students will explore the Campaigns of Gardasil and Cervarix to find out their use of Government bodies as façade to lure the public to consult doctors about the drugs.

title: Gender and Culture
requirements:
UGEC2653 is double-coded with ANTH2310. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2310, GDRS1001, GENA2192 or UGEC1209.

description: (UGEC2653 is double-coded with ANTH2310.) This course looks at the relationship between gender and culture, by comparing women and men in societies with different modes of production and social organization. Through analysing gender roles, enculturation process, kinship, division of labour by gender, power and control and social development, students will understand how culture influences the concept of gender and its related behaviour among human groups.
outcome: After taking this course, students will be able to: analyze gender and sexual diversities in different cultures explain how gender and culture can be studied systematically discuss major theories explaining gender and sexuality and use those theories to explain contemporary gender issues demonstrate how taken-for-granted ideas of gender shape our everyday lives

title: From Madness to Mental Health
requirements:
UGEC2654 is double-coded with ANTH2321. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2321.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2654 is double-coded with ANTH2321.) This course examines mental illness and mental health as subjective experiences, social processes, and objects of scientific knowledge and practice. It invites students to explore human experiences that are labelled as abnormal or pathological, to understand the expert knowledge and technologies employed to remedy these conditions, and to think about the complex relationships between them and the broader social and cultural contexts. Readings are drawn from psychiatric anthropology or anthropology of mental health, clinical case studies, and memoirs. They are chosen to reflect an interdisciplinary scope that includes social sciences, psychiatry itself, and the layman’s/patient’s perspective.

title: Indian Cultures and Society
requirements:
UGEC2655 is double-coded with ANTH2324. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2324 or 3324. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2655 is double-coded with ANTH2324.) This course is an anthropological introduction to contemporary India, its social life and diverse cultures. India is home to more than a billion people, who look differently, speak various languages, practice different religions, and have distinct rituals, cuisines, and music. It is one of the world’s powers with global economic, political, and intellectual influence. Moreover, it shares important ties in the sphere of philosophy, religion, and medicine with China and other Asian societies. Therefore, students will learn about India’s place both in the world and the Asian region, including its ties with Hong Kong. Students will also develop an understanding of the country’s diversity and complex social phenomena such as kinship, communalism, caste system, tribe, third gender, and class. We will discuss pressing issues and theoretical debates related to globalization, sexuality, social movements, religious conflicts, public health, environment, and labor, and how these issues have been shaped by post-colonial politics and current transnational processes.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to do the following:    understand and analyze the diversity of Indian society in terms of region, caste, class, religion, language, gender, and other sociocultural divisions    identify and compare the main ideas of various schools of philosophy and religion that originated in the Indian subcontinent    describe and give examples of the everyday life of Indian women and men, as well as hijras, and other persons who identify differently    explain the impact of India’s colonial history on its modern society    examine the role of popular culture, political processes, and the global economy in the lives of Indians in India and abroad    explain the cultural influences of India on the Asian region and the world    critically assess the academic literature, news, and public discourses about various aspects of the Indian society
syllabus: Indian population in terms of linguistic, cultural, and regional diversity; Indo-European and Dravidian languages as the major linguistic groups in India; Differences between South and North India, special positions of the North East, Kashmir, and the Andaman islands   Caste system (varna, jati), Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (indigenous groups) The division of the Indian society into castes and those considered to be outside the caste system. History and contemporary practices related to caste discrimination and privilege; the place of the indigenous groups known as tribals or Adivasi   hijra (third gender) Communities of people who identify neither men nor women   India’s independence, Partition (of India and Pakistan) The significance  of 1947 Indian independence from the British colonial rule, the establishment of India and Pakistan, and its impact on present-day India   Hinduism, Islam, Sikhism, Jainism, religious festivals (Diwali, oli) Different religions as well as their rituals, beliefs, festivals, political representations, and family practices   Arranged marriage, extended family, modern femininities and masculinities The significance of family relations and arranged marriages in India; different models of being a woman and being a man in India, specifically Indians imagine themselves as “traditional” or “modern” women and men   Yoga, Ayurveda, Indian sports and medicine History and contemporary practices of Indian health traditions of Yoga and Ayurveda; how Indians take care of their health and body, different sports they play   Curry and other Indian foods Regional differences in foods; the impact of colonial history on contemporary habits and preferences in eating, cooking and dining   Bollywood and Indian popular culture The cultural, economic, and political importance of the Bollywood industry; other regional film industries in India   Migration, Indians in Hong Kong Indian diasporas around the world; the history and current processes of migration of Indians to Hong Kong; the experiences of locally born Indians in Hong Kong

title: Working Cultures – Understanding Work in the 21st Century
requirements:
UGEC2656 is double-coded with ANTH2550. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2550.
Co-requisite: Any course with "UGFH" or "UGFN" as prefix (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2656 is double-coded with ANTH2550.) Work is a central practice and system of human production, innovation, social organization, and cooperation. Focusing on the work-place as 'working cultures', this course offers an anthropological perspective to understand how work is a matter of place, time, power, and meanings. We will further explore how current social, technological, and cultural transformations of work can be understood across places, in their historic continuities and disruptions. Each week the course analyzes, discusses, and rethinks a key concept in the anthropology of work: Class, time, race, gender, value, craft, ownership, creativity, autonomy, discipline, etc. Through reading contemporary ethnographies of different workplaces and circumstances, students will learn the analysis and theory of work in familiar or unexpected forms, as well as in different organizational settings from the office, factory, workshop, home, to online platforms. This course will further give the students the tools to systematically connect their own observations of work to writing about working cultures.
outcome: By the end of this course, students will be able to:   • Understand the intrinsic value of work as individual practice and social organization of human production. • Understand work's cultural diversity as well as its more general structures and patterns. • Know different anthropological perspectives of work and be able to use them in different contexts. • Comprehend and be able to apply the different theories explaining transforming or stable relations, organizations, and processes of work. • Be able to use anthropological modes of understanding, to think critically and perceptively about one's society and the world. • Read ethnography critically • Understand how theory is used in doing ethnography and writing ethnography
syllabus: This course will be divided in two parts: ‘Part I: Issues of Work Reloaded’; ‘Part II: Think work Differently’.   Part I: Issues of Work Reloaded This part will comprise about six weeks of instruction. After the introduction session, each week will explore a central social issue of work though a contemporary lens: Working Class I: Gender in the Global Factory, Working Class II: Race in Migration, Working Time, Working Place and Space, Working Self   Part II: Think Work Differently This part comprises the final seven weeks and will aim to challenge traditional understandings of work by showing how the conditions, experiences, and organization of work have changed: Working Craft, Working on Demand, Working Service, Working for Free?, Working Skill, Working Platforms, Working Capitalism
required_readings: Working Class I: Gender in the Global Factory   Work-places are social institutions that reproduce various relationships of society. By analyzing international technology hardware-production in Mexico, we will see how different ways of task organization, hiring practices, and promotion regimes shape gendered production as much as class and gender relations beyond the factory.   Salzinger, Leslie. 2003. "Chapter 1: Ways of Seeing", "Chapter 4: Bringing Fantasies to Life: Panoptimex" + "Chapter 5: Re-formulating the 'Traditional Mexican Woman': Particimex". In: Genders in Production: Making Workers in Mexico's Global Factories. Berkeley: University of California Press.   Working Class II: Race in Migration Following high-skilled IT-workers from India to Berlin this ethnography explores how immaterial work in an office can be embodied and ascribed to race rather than skill. Understanding work and its hierarchies within transnational and local class aspirations and shifting racial stereotypes, we will explore the experience of work as both empowering and discriminatory.   Amrute, Sareeta. 2016. "Introduction: Cognitive Bodies, Cognitive Work (until p. 18)", "Chapter 2: The Postracial Body". In: Encoding Race, Encoding Class. Indian IT Workers in Berlin. Durham: Duke University Press.   Working Place and Space All work-places exist in multiples spaces from global markets, supply chains, nation-states, to cities. Through the case of women working the night shift in Mumbai's call-center industry, we will see how social mobility and the roles of women in relations of work, leisure, family, and self are impacted by social norms of who should work at night.   Patel, Reena. 2010. "Introduction (until p. 18)", "Chapter 4: Traveling at Night". In: Working the Night Shift: Women in India's Call Center Industry. Stanford: Stanford University Press.   Working Time Time is crucial for structuring work and pay. Contemporary work often reorganizes time and new, flexible time regimes revolutionize our understanding of the work day. This week explores, on the one hand, time as valuable or wasted in the contemporary NGO-industry. On the other hand, we will look at time in terms of flexibility, autonomy, but also as source of anxiety for independent taxi drivers in New York.   Sheldon, Zachary. 2021. "Managing the Humanitarian Workplace: Capitalist Social Time and Iraqi Refugees in the United States." In: Anthropology of Work Review 42 (1 ): 35- 46.   Occhiuto, Nicolas. 2017. "Investing in Independent Contract Work: The Significance of Schedule Control for Taxi Drivers". In: Work and Occupations 44(3): 268 - 295.   Working Self Work is often not just a job, but a part of ourselves. But where are the boundaries between work as what we do or who we are? Through the case of sex workers in San Francisco, we will discuss themes of authenticity in customer relations, alienation, self-fulfilment, control, and abuse in service work.   Bernstein, Elizabeth. 2007. "Chapter 4: The Privatization of Public Women". In: Temporarily Yours - Intimacy, Authenticity, and the Commerce of Sex. Chicago: University of Chicago Press.   Working Service Similar service work like taking care of people can take place in drastically different settings from someones house to a luxury hotel. While some workers perform their duties in public, others are confined to the domestic and intimate spaces of other people's living spaces. By contrasting the management of domestic helpers in Hong Kong with luxury hotel workers in San Francisco, we will think about how work discipline and evaluation influences performance, but also how the setting of work allows or prevents abuse.   Constable, Nicole. 2017. "Chapter 5: Household Rules and Relations." In: Maid to Order in Hong Kong: Stories of Migrant Workers. Ithaca: Cornell University Press.   Sherman, Rachel. 2007. "Chapter 2: Managing Autonomy." In: Class Acts- Service and Inequality in Luxury Hotels. Berkeley: University of California Press.   Working Craft Practices and skill of work are often passed on, refined, and perfected through generations of practitioners. The skill of artisans and craft-workers has often been romanticized as traditional and pure. Through the reinvention of bartenders as highly skilled and creative makers in postindustrial New York, this week aims to understand how professions transform, become 'cool', and reinvent  themselves.   Ocejo, Richard. 2017. “Introduction: A Stroll through the Market” + “Chapter 1: The Cocktail Renaissance”. In: R. Ocejo. Masters of Craft: Old Jobs in the New Urban Economy. Princeton: Princeton University Press.   Working on Demand What is creativity? What is a copy? Exploring the world of the now famous, hand-painting makers of oil painting reproductions in Dafen village, we will see what makes an artist or a worker, as well as the shifting boundary between copyrights and copy.   Wong, Winnie. 2014. "Introduction: After the Copy (until p. 22)" + "Chapter 4: Step 18: 'Sign Vincent"'[selections]. In: Van Gogh on Demand - China and the Readymade. Chicago: University of Chicago Press.   Working Platforms Social media platforms drastically transform employment relationships, modes of contract and payment, but also meanings of profession and occupation. Through the online communities and marketplaces of game designers and car sharing drivers, we will see how work becomes more individualized or more embedded online.   Schwartz, David. 2018. “Embedded in the Crowd: Creative Freelancers, Crowdsourced Work, and Occupational Community”. In: Work and Occupations 45 (3). Pp. 255-282.   Surie, Aditi and Jyothi Koduganti. 2016. “The Emerging Nature of Work in Platform Economy: Companies in Bengaluru, India: The Case of Uber and Ola Cab Drivers”. In: International and Comparative Labour Studies 5(3): 1 – 30.   Working for Free? Why do we work for free? Is that even possible? By looking at seemingly 'un-worklike' activities of women and promoters in the international party circuits, we ask how we can understand work beyond traditional relations of employment or exchange.   Mears, Ashley. 2020. "Chapter 3: The Potlach" + "Chapter 4: Trafficking at Model Camp". In: Very Important People - Status and Beauty in the Global Party Circuit. Princeton: Princeton University Press.   Working Skill Who has skills? What are skills? Understanding the complex social organization of building football stadiums in Qatar, this week explores how people know what to do if it has never been done before. We will further understand skill as embodied practice and matter of recognition.   lskander, Natasha. 2021. "Chapter 3: How Skill is Embodied ... ". In: Does Skill Make Us Human? Migrant Workers in 21st Century Qatar and Beyond. Princeton: Princeton University Press.   Working Capitalism Is all work productive? Is all work meaningful? Through this critique of contemporary capitalism as unproductive system, we will discuss the meaning of work and how to imagine new work practices in the future.   Graeber, David. 2018. "Chapter 1: What is a Bullshit Job" + "Chapter 4: What is it like to have a Bullshit Job?". Bullshit Jobs -A Theory. New York: Anholt & Schuster. Selections.

title: Culture and Business
requirements:
UGEC2662 is double-coded with ANTH2510. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2510. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2662 is double-coded with ANTH2510.)  Culture is ubiquitous in every aspect of societies, including how we do business. This course will examine the role of culture in contemporary business and study work and management in industrial societies anthropologically. Students will be introduced to the cultural logics of business practices, particularly business operations, organization and management through ethnographic explorations of different cultures, locales and sociohistorical settings. The aims of the course are twofold. First, it reveals cultural aspects and the cultural mechanisms of business. It shows the significance of culture in the business world, as well as the cultural significance of business. Second, it attempts to put anthropology into business practice. It demonstrates to students how anthropological knowledge and methodologies can be applied to business operations and help to achieve business goals. By examining the themes including but not limited to the indoctrination of work ethics, labor relations, gender and racial issues in the workplace, capitalism and its discontents, and responses to and actions upon market capitalism in terms of both production and consumption, the course attends to these Sustainable Development Goals: No Poverty (SDG#1), Gender Equality (SDG#5), Decent Work and Economic Growth (SDG#8), Reduced Inequalities (SDG#10), Responsible Consumption and Production (SDG#12), and Partnerships for the Goals (SDG#17).
outcome: After the completion of this course, students will:  Understand and appreciate the cultural dimensions of business operations and organization in different historical, political, and social settings;  Acquire the necessary ethnographic skills to study diverse aspects of business operations and organization;  Be able to rethink and challenge the existing assumptions regarding business practices in the modern world;  Gain the analytical tools to examine issues of over-consumption, over-production, dispossession, oppression, and other relevant discontent under global capitalism;  Be able to examine critically the role SDGs could play in addressing disparities and injustices in the world;  Understand the importance of building a more inclusive, equal and diverse society.
syllabus: The course is structured in three parts. Part I Culture in Business explores the cultural dimensions of workplaces and corporate management. We begin with an overview of the temporal and spatial reconfigurations since industrialization in order to discern modern work ethics, followed by explorations of dynamics in the workplace. Next, we will explore discourses in shaping corporate operations and management, and consider (and challenge) the ideas of economization, maximization, auditing and accountability. This part decodes life in business settings, and practices in corporations. Part II Business Ventures in the Globalizing World situates the discussions in current trends of capitalism. We will look into what makes us buy and spend, and how traditional values and modern business practices mingle. It raises the question of whether we are really emancipated under the fashion of decentralization by exploring the gig economy and the phenomenon of self-enterprising. We will also examine how we can build a more inclusive, diverse and equal society by finding a new way out from the existing business ideologies and practices. Part III Anthropology and the Business World discusses how to apply anthropology in business settings, looking into how and why anthropology and anthropologists are important to the private sector, and broadly speaking, to the modern capitalist world. The course concludes by contemplating whether business is really business. Overall, through the examinations of how we are taught to work, produce, and buy, the imperative of gender and racial stereotypes in the workplace, turns in capitalism and the rise of new economies and the pertinent social and cultural phenomena, the course addresses the following Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs): No Poverty (SDG#1), Gender Equality (SDG#5), Decent Work and Economic Growth (SDG#8), Reduced Inequalities (SDG#10), Responsible Consumption and Production (SDG#12), and Partnerships for the Goals (SDG#17). Core topics: Week 1         Course Introduction Week 2         Seeing Business Anthropologically (SDGs 17) Part I          Culture in Business Week 3         Space, Time and Work Ethics (SDGs 8, 10) Week 4         Gender, Race/Ethnicity, and Communication in the Workplace (SDGs 5, 8, 10) Week 5         Corporatization, Economization and Maximization (SDGs 1, 8, 10, 12) Week 6         Audit Culture and Accountability (SDGs 8) Week 7         Mid-term Test Part II         Business Ventures in the Globalizing World Week 8         The Making of Consumers (SDGs 10, 12) Week 9         Fieldtrip to a Social Enterprise/ a Social Innovation Project/ an exhibition about reindustrialization in Hong Kong Week 10       The Gig Economy and Self-enterprising (SDGs 1, 8, 10) Week 11       Ethical-Political Consumerism and Social Entrepreneurialism (SDGs 1, 5, 8, 10, 12, 17) Part III        Anthropology and the Business World Week 12       Applying Anthropology to Business Practice (SDGs 10, 17) Week 13       Conclusion: Is Business Really Business?

title: Sports and Culture
requirements:
UGEC2664 is double-coded with ANTH2390. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2390.
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2664 is double-coded with ANTH2390.)This course will examine the role and importance of sports in different societies and cultures, in the present and the past. Sports are often thought of as trivial, or as unimportant games to amuse young people. But in the wealthiest countries, sports represent huge portions of GDP and are important topics of daily conversation. Almost half the world watched the 2010 football/soccer World Cup. Sports have been compared to religions in their ability to unite people and to inspire fanatical devotion.The academic study of sports is interdisciplinary, with contributions from psychologists, historians, gender studies scholars, sociologists and anthropologists. This course will take an interdisciplinary approach while emphasizing anthropology’s focus on culture, on the experience of participants, and on both symbolic and political-economy aspects of sports. Topics will include Race and Performance, Sports and Rituals, Sports as Moral Education, Gender and Sexuality in Sport, Sports and Nationalism, Globalization of Sport, the Olympics, and Sports Stars and the Media. Students will be expected to do a research project for the course.
outcome: Students who have taken this course will:  be able to see and understand the cultural and historical nature of sports;  understand the roles that sports play in modern societies;  know how to apply fieldwork methods to research a group’s sub-culture, including implicit and explicit rules;  be able to analyze the elements of competition, cooperation, luck and skill, and other variables that make sports entertaining to play and watch and talk about; be able to analyze and appreciate other sports that they will encounter later in life.
syllabus: Core Topics: 1) Introduction: The Importance of Sport 2) The Creation of Modern Sports 3) Biocultural Aspects: Genes, Race and Performance 4) The Rituals of Sports and Sport as Ritual 5) Sports as Moral Education 6) Gender and Sexuality in Sport 7) Sports, National Identity and Nationalism   Optional Topics: 8) Sports and Globalization 9) Sport and the Body 10) The Culture and Politics of the Olympics 11) Sports Stars and Sports Media 12) Sports and Class and Ethnicity 13) Case Studies in Modern Sports 14) Case Study: Rugby 15) Case Study: Baseball 16) Sports in Pre-capitalist Societies 17) Sports Violence

title: Social Media and Culture
requirements:
UGEC2665 is double-coded with ANTH2540. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2540. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2665 is double-coded with ANTH2540.) This course addresses the ways in which social media and other related interactions in cyberspace have become a central element in the everyday lives of humans across the globe in the 21st Century. Our modern lives are now largely interwoven with digital technologies that have not only changed our own cultures, but also have brought forth new cultural forms through mobile phone technologies, networked “smart”-products, and cultural groupings only possible through digital means. The course approaches the anthropology of these digital cultures through its main themes—the transformation and expansion of social media, social research online, the intermixing of our online and offline lives, critical social issues of online lives, and the question of posthumanism. These themes are addressed explicitly in the course, and are also the subtexts of the different lectures, readings, and project work. Students will learn the techniques of online fieldwork and referencing. They will explore a diverse array of new ethnographies on social media: on gender, political movements, online dating, hacking, and gaming culture. These ethnographies also serve to model online social research and provide examples of methodology and design. The social consequences of cyberspace are addressed in the topics of internet pornography, addiction, surveillance, activism, and social networking. Gender and identity issues are a continuous theme throughout the course, highlighting how online lives accentuate already existing dynamics. Hong Kong connections to these subjects will also be critically discussed, often drawing on topical themes presented on blogs and forums. Students will learn of the philosophical questions of posthumanism and the nature of technologically mediated human culture. This serves as a philosophical ballast to the course allowing students to reflect personally on their own experiences and how technology has and will continue to shape their lives. The role of anthropology in understanding and capturing human culture in this context anchors on the investigation of how technology is possibly making us ‘more’ human than previous forms of cultural life.

title: Culture and Mind
requirements:
UGEC2667 is double-coded with ANTH2320. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2320. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2667 is double-coded with ANTH2320.) How can we understand the minds of other people? Do people in different cultures or societies feel and think in different ways? How do childhood experiences affect people and shape or even determine what kinds of persons they will become? What is it like to be mentally abnormal or even pathological? Do people in different cultures or societies experience, understand, and treat psychopathology in different ways? This course examines psychological experiences—feelings, perceptions, thoughts, and motivations—from social and cross-cultural perspectives. It sets out to explore the intersection between anthropology, a field that typically turns to the exotic other, and psychology, a field that often takes the universality of mental activities and mechanisms for granted. Specific focus is placed upon how ethnographers, clinicians, and researchers with training in both fields grapple with various mental phenomena and different ways of understanding them. As most of the materials are drawn from psychological anthropology, this course also serves as an eclectic introduction to this subfield, which was once influential in the history of American anthropology.

title: Interpersonal Violence
requirements:
UGEC2680 is double-coded with SOWK2200. 
Not for Social Work Majors; and students who have taken SOWK2200.
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2680 is double-coded with SOWK2200.) The purposes of this course are to provide students a basic understanding of violence that takes place in our daily life in the contexts of intimate relationship, family, school and community and to arouse their consciousness of contemporary values of equality, human rights and social justice. Various concepts and theories of violence will be introduced to explore the nature, causes, consequences and trends of violence in different aspects of life. Emphasis will be placed on the issues of interpersonal violence in contemporary societies. Social policy and provisions to prevent and eliminate interpersonal violence will also be discussed.

title: Globalization and Politics
requirements:
UGEC2683 is double-coded with GPAD2355.
Not for Government and Public Administration Majors; and students who have taken GLSD2301, GPAD2355 or UGEC2352.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2683 is double-coded with GPAD2355.)  This course introduces undergraduate students to the key concepts, theoretical frameworks, and main political discussions/reflections related to globalization. Globalization itself is introduced in a broad sense not limited by the economic aspect but a common experience of social change. For example, global environmental challenges, the common threat of nuclear crisis, the controversy between sovereignty and human rights, and the North-South divide. With both the historical and thematic perspectives, the class engages students with most recent research and debate on the topic. On the one hand, the class encourages students to relate their own experiences and observations in their own societies to digest what globalization is and what its impacts are. On the other hand, it also leads them to reflect on politics and social development in their own societies, in the context of globalization.

title: Social Work and Cultural Diversity
requirements:
UGEC2684 is double-coded with SOWK2202. 
Not for Social Work Majors; and students who have taken SOWK2202.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2684 is double-coded with SOWK2202.)  This course provides students with fundamental and systematic knowledge on issues related to ethnic and cultural diversity. Apart from introducing contemporary theories and conceptual perspectives about cultural sensitivity and cultural intelligence, this course will also highlight major discourses and challenges concerning access, equity, social inclusiveness, cultural assimilation and integration which have substantial impact on ethnic minorities as well as social harmony. Through participation in small group projects, guided community tours, and face-to-face interaction with different ethnic groups, students will be able to develop an awareness of the differences in values, beliefs, life-style and interpersonal relatedness between themselves and people of other ethnic background. Basic skills, knowledge and attitude required of cultural intelligence, equal-opportunity legislations, social policies, service provision in meeting the needs of ethnic minorities, and measures to promote mutual acceptance and social inclusiveness will be discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1.            Acquire knowledge of the key concepts and theoretical perspectives of multiculturalism, related social policies and service delivery system; 2.            Apply an intercultural perspective to understand the struggles, challenges and socio-cultural barriers of ethnic groups in Hong Kong. 3.            Evaluate the impact of culture on individuals and/or groups’ values, beliefs, behaviours, attitudes, preferences and life pursuits; 4.            Develop awareness in cultural sensitivity and acquire cultural competence as well as intercultural intelligence

title: Social Innovation and Social Change for Good
requirements:
UGEC2686 is double-coded with SOWK2204.
Not for Social Work Majors; and students who have taken SOWK2204.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2686 is double-coded with SOWK2204.)  This course prepares students to learn from the emerging practices of social innovations in tackling with challenges in social, economic, cultural and political development in Hong Kong, the Greater China region and beyond. Students will acquire analysis, knowledge and strategies of social innovations, the processes of social change in creating social values. The scope of social innovations includes that of social entrepreneurs or social innovators in NGOs, communities, social movements, non-profit organizations, and business as well as the public sector. The course will examine cases of social innovations that have catalyzed important positive social change through the market, the nonprofit sector, the community, the public sector as well as the spaces among those four sectors. Experiential learning will be integrated along the course delivery, such as programmme visits, dialogue with social entrepreneurs, staff members or service users. Students are encouraged to experience these operations, so as to analyze the development issues, the social values and innovations in offering practical solutions to poverty and social inequalities, unemployment and livelihood, civic and community engagement, fair trade as well as sustainable development. The course will provide inspirations as well as know-hows for students who are concerned about the articulation of local with global and regional issues and like to develop innovative actions to change the society for good.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to ·         Realise how social innovations work to target social issues, creating social values through innovative strategies in various sectors as well as cross sectoral collaboration; ·         Recognize the basic know-hows of social innovation such as design thinking, community or civic engagement, collaboration, prototyping and lean start-up; ·         Apprehend how social innovation leverage their work and impact to catalyze changes in the broader community, economy or political sphere. ·         Critically evaluate how social innovation can fulfil the objectives of coping with the challenges in the social, economic, cultural and political spheres. ·         Acquire personal experience and prepare to taking own responsibilities as global citizen and ready to be social innovator / social entrepreneur in tackling the local, regional and global development challenges.

description: Political analyses of international and local current affairs. Selected issues will be discussed from both theoretical and practical perspectives.
